T1.label: North American Premiumisation Drives Revenue Re-Acceleration
T1.description: Revenue growth sustains 8-10%+ pa; pricing and supply chain diversification restore gross margins to 37%+; operating leverage drives EBIT expansion
T1.plain_english: This is the bull case — Breville's premium brand keeps growing despite tariff headwinds, and margins recover as pricing actions and supply chain diversification take hold.
T1.what_to_watch: 1H FY27 gross margin (recovery above 37%?); FY26 EBIT vs A$204.6M; management commentary on pricing.
T1.upside: Re-rating toward A$38-40 if gross margins recover to 37%+ and revenue sustains above 10%.
T1.risk_plain: If tariff costs cannot be fully passed through, margins stay compressed and the premium multiple erodes.

T2.label: European Sage Brand Accelerates Revenue Mix Shift
T2.description: Sage brand grows 15%+ pa in Continental Europe; European segment becomes a material contributor to group revenue and earnings
T2.plain_english: The European optionality thesis — Sage is where Breville was in North America 10 years ago. As European espresso culture and premium appliance spending grows, Sage captures disproportionate share.
T2.what_to_watch: Management commentary on Sage revenue growth; any European segment disclosure.
T2.upside: If Sage revenue breaks out, the group growth rate accelerates and justifies the premium multiple.
T2.risk_plain: If European consumer sentiment remains weak and Sage growth disappoints, the Europe thesis is delayed.

T3.label: Consumer Discretionary Slowdown Pressures Premium Demand
T3.description: US and European consumers reduce premium discretionary spending; revenue growth decelerates below 5%; tariff-compressed margins amplify operating deleverage
T3.plain_english: The macro bear case — if tariff-driven inflation erodes consumer purchasing power and confidence falls, premium kitchen appliances are discretionary and deferrable.
T3.what_to_watch: US consumer confidence; retail channel inventory; De'Longhi revenue growth as a proxy.
T3.risk_plain: Revenue deceleration below 5% plus compressed margins would trigger a de-rating to 20-25x P/E.

T4.label: US Tariff + Competitive Intensity Erodes Margin Structurally
T4.description: US tariffs on China and Vietnam manufactured goods persist or escalate; gross margins structurally erode toward 33-34%; premium multiple collapses
T4.plain_english: The structural bear case — if tariff costs cannot be recovered through pricing and supply chain diversification fails to offset the cost impact, Breville's margin profile deteriorates permanently.
T4.what_to_watch: US tariff policy developments; 1H FY27 gross margin; Vietnam supply chain progress.
T4.risk_plain: Gross margins below 35.5% for 3 consecutive halves would drive P/E compression from 35x to 22-25x.

big_picture: Breville Group (ASX: BRG) — 1H FY26 revenue A$1,098.7M (+10.1%) with gross margin compression to 35.4% (from 36.7%) from US tariff impacts. FY26 EBIT guidance maintained at slight increase on FY25 A$204.6M. Premium brand resilience intact; margin recovery timeline is the key uncertainty at 35.4x P/E.
